results.title: Playing with numbers (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The main part of this program concerns an examination of the types of numbers that arise. Rational numbers, algebraic numbers and irrational numbers are illustrated and discussed.

results.title: Playing with fire
results.creator_credit: National Fire Protection Association. Public Affairs Division, Christopher Knight and Frank Cantor
results.brief_description: Two children take some matches from home and set fire to a truck, which in the process of exploding burns them both badly. A doctor explains that dangers should be explained to children as so often in the domestic situation children are put at risk when with care and commonsense these can be avoided.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Fire Protection Association. Public Affairs Division, Christopher Knight and Frank Cantor

results.title: Playing together
results.brief_description: A light-hearted impression in music, words and pictures of the many different sporting activities enjoyed by young and old throughout Britain. It stresses the need for the opportunities to learn sport and its value as a character-builder. Professional sportsmen throughout the country have the same love of the game and sense of fair play which is acknowledged all over the world. Closing sequences of the film show international teams playing football, epitomising the goodwill which is promoted by sport and sportsmen between people and nations of every land.

results.title: Playing the environment game
results.creator_credit: Pictures That Move and Mick Csaky
results.brief_description: One of London’s outstanding features is the historic architecture, and this film shows three groups of people fighting changes, including developers against community groups. The process of corporate land acquisition is illustrated, and the effects of this on local residents and council plans for land.

results.title: Playing for time
results.creator_credit: Syzygy Productions, Linda Yellen and Daniel Mann
results.brief_description: Based on the memoirs of Fania Fenelon in her book The Musicians of Auschwitz and written for television by Arthur Miller, this feature length program stars Vanessa Redgrave in the role of Fenelon, a French-Jewish cabaret singer who was working in Paris at the time of the Nazi invasion and who was eventually shipped off to the Nazi death camp in Auschwitz in 1944. Fenelon, along with several other women musicians, is forced to perform for the condemned inmates facing the gas chamber in exchange for her own survival. As long as the group keep performing so their lives are spared and no more aware of this is their leader Alma Rose (Jane Alexander). Conflict and tension increases between these two women as each explores their soul and conscience in this inhumane and degrading struggle for life. For the viewer it raises many issues of the human condition and what price survival but perhaps more controversial is the fact that Vanessa Redgrave is well-known for her anti-Zionist stance, causing wide opposition by many including the real-life Fenelon, to Redgrave’s appearance in the film. However Redgrave puts in a magnificent performance winning her an Emmy Award, along with Emmy Awards for scriptwriter Arthur Miller, supporting actress Jane Alexander, and Oustanding Dramatic Special Award for the film itself. Cast also includes Maud Adams, Shirley Knight, Marisa Berenson, Robin Bartlett, Mady Kaplan. A compelling and poignant story.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Syzygy Productions, Linda Yellen and Daniel Mann
